title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
partialText: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.

title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
partialText: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.

title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
partialText: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.

title: How the H-1B Visa Debate Is Driving a Wave of Racism Against South Asians
partialText: A dispute over the impact of H-1B visas on U.S. workers has been overshadowed by racist rhetoric, with troubling echoes of the great replacement conspiracy theory.

title: The Quiet Architect of Trump’s Global Trade War
partialText: Jamieson Greer, a low-key lawyer from a working-class background, is rewriting the rules of the global economy at the president’s behest.

title: How a Trump Tax Break Rescued Horse Racing
partialText: Owners spent nearly $1.5 billion last year on racehorses, a big increase over 2024. A new tax provision allows them to immediately deduct the full cost of the purchase.

title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
partialText: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.

title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
partialText: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.

title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
partialText: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.

title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
partialText: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.

title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
partialText: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.

title: Will 2026 Be the Year of the ‘Soonicorn’?
partialText: As venture capital funding pours into start-ups large and small, more firms are pitching themselves as the next big thing.

title: What C.E.O.s Are Worried About
partialText: Fractured politics, disruptive technologies and a distrust in institutions are making it harder to focus on the traditional tasks of growing sales and profits.

title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
partialText: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.

title: How ICE Is Pushing Tech Companies to Identify Protesters
partialText: The DHS is flooding social media companies with administrative subpoenas to identify accounts that are protesting ICE. Social media companies have pushed back but are largely complying. Our tech reporter, Sheera Frenkel, explains.

title: Software? No Way. We’re an A.I. Company Now!
partialText: As their stocks tank, software makers are rebranding themselves as A.I. innovators. Sparkle emojis are everywhere, but some efforts have been more successful than others.

title: Can You Rely on A.I. to Translate Love?
partialText: A.I. translation has become a huge industry, but how accurate is it? Our tech reporter, Kashmir Hill, explores its successes and failures through a couple who relies on of A.I. translation to communicate.

title: T.S.A. Workers Brace for Another Shutdown They Didn’t Cause
partialText: As Congress leaves town without funding their department, airport security officers wonder, “How many more times am I going to be able to do this?”

title: Sick Detainees Describe Poor Care at CoreCivic ICE Facilities
partialText: Problems at detention centers operated by CoreCivic extend far beyond recent measles outbreaks.

title: The 2026 Milan Olympics Has Its Eyes on Grana Padano
partialText: Grana Padano cheese is trying to capture some of the international spotlight on Italy, appearing on billboards and social media — and in high-protein muffins for athletes.

title: How A.I. Salaries Are Causing Couples to Rethink Money in Relationships
partialText: The artificial intelligence frenzy is creating personal fortunes rarely seen in modern technology and changing people’s attitudes about fairness and money in relationships.

title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
partialText: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.

title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
partialText: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.

title: White House Sees Win After 2 Strong Economic Reports
partialText: Solid jobs data and a soft inflation reading for January are welcome news for President Trump. But the bigger economic picture is less encouraging.

title: Bessent Pushes Senate on Fed Confirmation Amid Backlash Over Criminal Inquiry
partialText: President Trump’s effort to get Kevin M. Warsh confirmed as the next Federal Reserve chair has been complicated by a criminal investigation into Jerome H. Powell.

title: Trying to Cut Costs? Start With Your Phone, Internet and Streaming Bills.
partialText: It’s cold outside — and a fine time to look over your bills and see where you can save.

title: Crises Everywhere, but the Markets Don’t Seem to Mind
partialText: Stocks have prospered while the world has plunged into disorder, an economist says. “Keep calm and carry on” may be the best investors can do.

title: U.S. Inflation Eased at Start of the Year
partialText: The Consumer Price Index fell in January to 2.4 percent from 2.7 percent a month

title: More Epstein Fallout for Goldman Sachs, DP World and Beyond
partialText: The Wall Street giant’s top lawyer, whose ties to Jeffrey Epstein had raised questions at the firm, has resigned. Other corporate leaders are also facing blowback.

title: The Hidden Number Driving U.S. Job Growth
partialText: After a year of just 181,000 new jobs, January’s 131,000 increase in the U.S. workforce was surprisingly positive. Ben Casselman, The New York Times’ chief economic correspondent, explains the numbers.

title: Another Government Shutdown? Here’s What Travelers Should Know.
partialText: It was not immediately clear whether passengers would face delays at airport security checkpoints in the coming days if a government shutdown does occur.

title: Meta Plans to Add Facial Recognition Technology to Its Smart Glasses
partialText: In an internal memo last year, Meta said the political tumult in the United States would distract critics from the feature’s release.

title: Christie’s to Auction 3 of Agnes Gund’s Art Jewels
partialText: A Rothko, a Twombly and a Surrealist box with a Medici princess by Joseph Cornell are estimated to sell for $145 million.

title: Conspiracy Theories Only Flourish With More Epstein Evidence
partialText: The dump of millions of documents has fueled a new wave of speculation, A.I.-generated hoaxes and foreign disinformation.

title: Crab Heist Puts Spotlight on Surge of Cargo Thefts
partialText: Stolen food and beverages, which are easier to offload than costly electronics, are driving an overall spike in cargo crimes, truckers, insurers and other experts say.

title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
partialText: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.

title: Amtrak’s Largest Train Revamp in 55 Years Is Coming Soon
partialText: Step inside the sprawling factory in California where the largest fleet replacement in Amtrak’s 55-year history is coming together piece by piece.

title: Venezuela’s Natural Gas, Not Oil, Might Be a Big Early Prize
partialText: The South American country has natural gas that could be extracted and exported quickly, but U.S. sanctions, which are now being eased, have stymied development.

title: Iran Turns to Digital Surveillance Tools to Track Down Protesters
partialText: As Iranian authorities restore some online services after crushing antigovernment demonstrations, they are using a technological dragnet to target attendees of the protests.

title: Goldman Sachs General Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler Resigns Over Epstein Ties
partialText: Kathryn Ruemmler, a former top Obama administration lawyer, is out at Goldman Sachs after emails showed a friendship with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein spanning many years.

title: El Paso Incident Highlights Gaps in America’s Drone Defense Industry
partialText: The U.S. has spent billions of dollars developing counter-drone technology, but much of it needs more testing in the real world.

title: Trump’s Actions Test the Fragile World of Air Travel
partialText: Last-minute announcements and abrupt changes by the Trump administration have caused confusion in an already strained U.S. aviation system.

title: Flexibility and Rising Costs Are Keeping Mothers at Work
partialText: Labor force participation for women with small children continues to float above prepandemic levels, thanks to flexible work setups — and rising costs.

title: Americans Are Paying the Bill for Tariffs, Despite Trump’s Claims
partialText: Research from the New York Fed confirms that U.S. companies and consumers are bearing tariff costs, despite the president’s assertions otherwise.

title: Europe Worries Trump Poses Threat to Its Financial and Tech Sovereignty
partialText: European leaders have been compelled to address the possibility of once-remote risks to the financial networks and technology that undergird their economies.

title: Dutch Prosecutors Fine Louis Vuitton Netherlands in Money Laundering Case
partialText: The Dutch subsidiary of the luxury brand agreed to pay a nearly $600,000 settlement in a money laundering and terrorism financing case.

title: South Korean Court Rules Against Women in LG Inheritance Lawsuit
partialText: The widow and two daughters of LG’s former chairman sought to invalidate an inheritance agreement, claiming they were deceived into forfeiting their rightful inheritance.

title: The Giant Super PACs Fighting Over A.I. Safety
partialText: Anthropic is pouring millions of dollars into a political action committee that will most likely face off against OpenAI.

title: States Say No Thanks to Trump Tax Cuts, Drawing Republican Fire
partialText: State income taxes often reflect federal policies, but Washington, D.C. and some states have taken steps to keep the latest Republican changes out of their tax codes.

title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
partialText: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
